oai_dc:dc.dc:title: State Colored Normal School's new Laboratory School, 1930
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Student-teachers and pupils outside the newly-built laboratory school. Originally opened in 1929 to both serve neighborhood children and function as a laboratory school for training teachers from State Colored Normal School, the name was changed in 1959 to the Harold L. Trigg Elementary School. The structure was demolished in 1988.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Dr. Herman Cooke Presides over State Teachers College Biology Lab
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Professor Herman G. Cooke not only served the institution as a professor of biology but he was the guardian angel of hundreds of student athlete who found paid work in his lab and benefitted from his academic oversight in their studies. Cooke frequently went on the road with athletic teams to assist the managers as well as ensure that homework assignments were completed.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: State Teachers College President Sidney David Williams, 1949

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: North Carolina-issued Confederate Currency, One Dollar
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: North Carolina-issued Confederate currency, $1 No. 3207. Obverse text reads, in part, "The STATE of NORTH CAROLINA/Will pay ONE DOLLAR to Bearer/at the Treasury on or before 1st Jan. 1866." Signed by C. Dewey, bottom right. Top corners, cartouches with the number "1" written in them. Central cartouche shows two human-like figures, flanked on the left by a shipping port and on the right by factory buildings; meant to highlight North Carolina's commercial strengths. Reverse is blank.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Money
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Copyright Orange County Historical Museum, Hillsborough, N.C. The images in this collection are made available for use in research, private study, and teaching. Prior permission from the Orange County Historical Museum is required for any commercial use.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: North Carolina-issued Confederate Currency, Fifty Cents
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: North Carolina-issued Confederate bill for fifty cents. Obverse: central image of a clipper ship at sea. Text written around image reads, "THE STATE OF NORTH CAROLINA/WILL PAY TO/BEARER AT/the Treasury on or before January 1st 1866/FIFTY CENTS." Signed by Thos. Lachorn [sp?]. Image box on right side of obverse shows decorative floral bouquet, on top of which is written, "BY AUTHORITY/of LAW."
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Money
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Copyright Orange County Historical Museum, Hillsborough, N.C. The images in this collection are made available for use in research, private study, and teaching. Prior permission from the Orange County Historical Museum is required for any commercial use.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: State of North Carolina Bills

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Pipe Organ
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Derrick and Felgemaker Pipe Organ Company.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Pipe organ and bench. The pewter pipes are in three rows with the visible pipes decorated with gold leaf and flowers. Made by Derrick and Felgemaker, (which is imprinted above keys), Erie PA, 1831. Used in Hillsborough in the Presbyterian Church. A similar organ by the same builder is in the Cathedral at Notre Dame, South Bend, Indiana. Leslie Derrick, grandchild of Silas Lusher Derrick, the organ maker, has provided information on the family which is in the acquisitions book.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Faculty and Distinguished guests at President Walter Nathaniel Ridley's Installation, 1959

He came to STC as the first African-American to earn an Ed.D from the University of Virginia.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Davie County Jail
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Mohney, Kirk Franklin.
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: Davie County Historical and Genealogical Society
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The National Register of Historic Places includes the old jail, built in 1839. Henry R. Austin, architect of the original courthouse, also designed the jail with jailers' living quarters on the first floor and the second floor divided into cell blocks. Used as a jail until 1909, Gaston E. Horn then converted the building to a private residence. Hugh S. Larew restored the building in 1970.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Cooleemee Band
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The mill organized the band with 20 members in 1917, providing uniforms and instruments. A.A. Hartman served as the first director, followed by Joe Nance, Ernest Fritz, Prof. Shaw, Roberts Mills, and Floyd A. Nail. The band performed for Christmas, 4th of July, picnics, and other amusements in the mill village. Some members later played with other bands, such as Wake Forest College, Clark Brothers Circus, Ringling Brothers Circus, and Sousa.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Bands; Brass instruments; Percussion instruments

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: View of a three-story sanatorium with two porches. Message on back of card reads: "Dear Ms. Britter I was very glad to hear such good news from your meetings I suppose you are all getting ready for Christmas now I hope it will be a happy one for you all I wish you could have such fine warm weather as we are having I hope Mr Crocket will stay with you another year I hope Charles King is all right by this time Love to all T A Kent" Addressed to: "Mrs Amzie Britter Mt Vernon Maine Route 39" Postmarked 22 December 1908.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Jane Eccles McGuire Portrait
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Dr. McGuire married Jane E. Eccles, daughter of John W. Eccles of Davie County, in 1859. Of this union were born five children, three dying in infancy, and a daughter, later in life. James Jr., the late husband of Mrs. Hattie McGuire of Mocksville was the only one of the children to survive and rear a family.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Cooleemee Plantation House
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Mohney, Kirk Franklin.
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: Davie County Historical and Genealogical Society
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Peter Hairston purchased the 2,500-acre tract of Cooleemee Plantation in 1817. His great-grandson, Peter Wilson Hairston, expanded the tract to 4,200 acres and constructed the imposing Greek Revival style plantation house from 1853-1855. The house stands 50 feet tall with twelve rooms, a large central hall, and self-supporting wooden staircase. Additional features include woodwork by Philadelphia craftsmen and plasterwork by Italian workmen. The house, listed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1973, remains private property of the Hairston family.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: National Register of Historic Places.
Hairston, Peter Wilson, 1819-1886.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Lee House
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Casselman, William A.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: During the Civil War, Mrs. Bailey was held at gunpoint by Stonestreet soldiers in the Lee House on Cartner Street when she resisted demands for money; a bed pillow was set on fire, but the soldiers left without harming her. The fire was quickly extinguished, with the only remaining evidence of the incident a charred wallboard on display at the library. The house was built in 1838 by Braxton Bryant Bailey.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Hotel Mocksville
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Hotel Mocksville opened in 1934. Owned and operated by J. Arthur Daniel, the only hotel in town had 22 rooms. With business strong, Daniel added a third floor in 1935. Traveling salesmen chose to stay at the hotel because of its good food. Chairs lined the sidewalk, allowing guests to enjoy the cooling evening air before retiring to their rooms at night.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Goat Man
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Charles "Ches" McCartney wandered throughout the country in a wagon pulled by a team of nine goats for close to 40 years (1930-1968). Wearing goatskin clothes, drinking goat's milk, and rarely bathing, the Goat Man preached and told tall tales wherever he went. Muggs Smith recalls seeing the Goat Man in Mocksville during the 1950s.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: John and Mariah Nail Mertz
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Swords Bro's.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Mocksville native Mariah Elizabeth Nail stood only 36 inches tall and weighed 48 pounds. She traveled throughout the United States and Europe with the circus as one of the world's smallest women. She met her diminutive husband, Major John Mertz, "Major Mite" while touring. The couple traveled with the Barnum Circus, Adam Forepaugh, and John Robinson Shows. They retired from the circus in 1911 and lived in Salisbury until their deaths.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Erwin Mills Cooleemee
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Erwin Mills Company established the town of Cooleemee, building the cotton mill on the South Yadkin River in 1899. In peak operation, the mill employed 1,800 workers. Until closing in 1969, the mill sponsored a broad range of recreational, social, religious, civic, and educational opportunities.

oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: Davie County Historical and Genealogical Society
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Jesse A. Clement built the plantation house around 1828 making it one of the oldest homes in the county. Rev. William F. Long, pastor of the First Presbyterian Church in Mocksville from 1958 to 1962, purchased the home in 1978 from the Clement heirs and restored it to its original condition. The National Park Service listed the house on the National Register of Historic Places in 1979.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Zion Chapel Methodist
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Mohney, Kirk Franklin.
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: Davie County Historical and Genealogical Society
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Built in 1892 for $250, the church features an L-shaped frame with the altar positioned at the intersection of the wings. The congregation met here until 1961 when a new brick church was completed. The picturesque church is one of few unaltered chapels in the county. Zion traces its roots to brush arbor meetings between 1758 and 1763, believed to have been held on the Daniel Ratledge grant land adjacent to the Georgia Road.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Courthouse with People
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Named for the settlement known as Mocks Old Field, Mocksville incorporated in 1839. Civic leaders erected the courthouse in the center of the one and one half acres set aside as a public square and business district. The business center of town shifted to the downtown square from present-day Salisbury Street. Town limits radiated one half mile in every direction from the new courthouse.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Courthouses--North Carolina.
Courthouses
Formation of Davie County;Biography

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: James McGuire House
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Built by Dr. James McGuire in the 1880s, the Philip Hanes family rented the house in 1901 before A. Turner Grant's purchase in 1910. The now-demolished structure stood on the site of the First Baptist church's current parking lot.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Courthouse Fire
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The top floor of the courthouse, badly damaged by the fire, required extensive rebuilding. The complete cost to repair the building including heating, plumbing, electrical, furnishings and a new clock totaled about $30,000, paid for by bonds sold to Wachovia Bank & Trust Co. of Winston-Salem.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: North Carolina-issued Confederate Currency, Three Dollars
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: North Carolina-issued Confederate currency. Three dollars, No. 1408. Obverse text reads, in part "THE STATE of NORTH CAROLINA/Will pay THREE DOLLARS to Bearer/Redeemable at the TREASURY on or before the/FIRST DAY OF JANUARY 1866." Cartouche at center shows classical scene: two woman, one standing and one seated, at the foot of a fluted column; cornucopia beside the seated figure. Signed by C. D. Dewey. "THREE" written vertical along both sides of the bill. Reverse is blank.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Sumner, William Hoke.
